I remember the reason of this error was the missspelling of the package path of the Exception  corrected by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/bd715659e1d28441aff3ca20b56ce3938ef3ee54. There is an Exception thrown while trying to import/use your own model that can't be found because of this wrong package path there.

So you have to recompile MXNet with Amalgamation for Android yourself and replace the .so in the WhatsThis app.

I think I found the error. It is in these lines https://github.com/ziyeqinghan/mxnet/blob/lstm/R-package/demo/rnn/lstm.R#L244-L245

```
init.states[[paste0("l", i, ".init.c")]] <- m$rnn.exec$arg.arrays[[paste0("l", i, ".last.c_output")]]
init.states[[paste0("l", i, ".init.h")]] <- m$rnn.exec$arg.arrays[[paste0("l", i, ".last.h_output")]]
```

`l1.last.c_output` is in `m$rnn.exec$outputs`, not in `m$rnn.exec$arg.arrays`

Please help to test it. If it works, you can update your PR according to it, or we can just merge that commit.

Ok. So here are some updates and questions after I tried implementing EASGD and EAMSGD (momentum EASGD) for single machine case. Anyone interested in implementing this one can have an idea on how to do so. Right now the result looks good. I did't post the code here because I went the nasty approach of modifying model.py and optimizer.py files. 

auther implementation for Torch link: [mpiT](https://github.com/sixin-zh/mpiT)

How to implement in MxNet:
1.  modify the _update_params_on_kvstore and implement everything according to paper,I used the kvstore to manage averaging weight, and you need to pass in optimizer to learning rate etc..
2. create a dummy optimizer which passes pushed gradient to weight.
3. (optional) if u are implementing EAMSGD, you need to create a velocity array in the train_multi_machine for momentum and pass it to _update_params_on_kvstore.
4. modify train_multi_machine so u can call modified _update_params_on_kvstore according to the optimizer object type. Basically using "if else" stuff.
5. on each epoch testing, you need to synchronize each worker weight once using weight stored in kvstore(the averaging weight author used, I took the mean of works which is a little different). Make a copy of original one before this action,cause each worker weight is different, and restore it back after testing.

Questions:
Is there any documents explaining multi machine updating details? How my modification on _update_params_on_kvstore  and optimizer affects dist_sync case? 

Now I'm trying to scale this algorithm for multiple machines. My brain messed up with this case as I have no experience on this. I did 2 experiments using dmlc_mpi.py both with n=2, s=1 but 2 different kvstore setup (dist_sync, dist_async). the dist_async works while the dist_sync failed converging. I did't expected dist_async to work as my single machine code is for sync case, the single machine async case is not tested (because I don't know how to do so, LOL. I guess dmlc_local might be a direction).
you need a kernel function to process GPU data. Check if MxNet can satisfy your need,otherwise you might need to implement gpu kernel code in .cu file.

Does mxnet provide a interface like `label.cpu_data()` in caffe?

you need to call NewTensor to create a CPU tensor and copy data there. After that you can do whatever you want on CPU. Be sure to free that temporary tensor after that, I crashed once before, LOL. If you are going use what you computed in future, I suggest you write some GPU code for better speed performance.

This is expected behavior, as _NDArray is native operator that have something to do with scripting side  customization. What you can do is rebuild the symbol on the python or other language native side, and load the parameters.

Yes, I think that is also counts as matmul
Yes, both symbolic execution and ndarray benefit from the dep engine

Spefically, both the unrolled RNN graph(symbolic executor) and imperative NDArray are lazily scheduled and will try to maximize the device utilization by scheduling things as soon as dependency is fulfilled, like what you talked about.

We have not yet have experiment on small batch setting yet. But your idea is indeed interesting and we would love to hear what are the results

You might want to also change environment variable, on the parallelism level on each GPU on such setting, see http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/env_var.html

MXNET_EXEC_NUM_TEMP  and MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS  are relevant env vars

It can be fixed by removing flags in dmlc-core/make/dmlc.mk line 14 and 15

One possible reason is that, the procedure you have runned still  occupied the GPU memory in terminal or python kernal. You can try to restart the terminal  or python kernal to release that.

Besides, you can run " nvidia-smi -l" in terminal to monitor the GPU use in real time to see whether the GPU memory is really working or not.

Hello @Lodewic and @thirdwing , I hope am not too late given that this thread is about 3 months old. ANyway I amstruggling with installing MxNet on windows with R. I have been using the cpu version but will like to migrate to thr gpu version.
Firstly, I have tried to follow the instructions on [http://myungjun-youn-demo.readthedocs.org/en/latest/build.html] but with no complete success yet. I have installed VS12 and the VS compiler.

When I tried to import mxnet from anaconda it did not work neither was I able to run the setup.py file through Anaconda. 

First question is, how can integrate mxnet with Anaconda given that Anaconda came pre-packed with its python and wasn't using the same package folder as python27.

My second question is that I am experiencing same as @Lodewic, I followed all his steps but on what platform will I run the command `R CMD INSTALL --no-multiarch` I am a bit lost there.

I guess both could due to break change in libmxnet's sum function. Since they might be related to internal tests.

I know what happened, because the c++ `sum` function is removed due to the name duplication. I renamed it to be `sum_internal`. The problem is I need to use the `axis` and `keepdims` argument which is not available in the old sum function.
cc @thirdwing @pluskid @javelinjs

Another approach is to make a more general sum directly in c++ side.

eventually things should go to c++ side. However, since we want to enable minpy support soon. I would recommend keep the current way.

Let us register the name by sum, but checks if the function already exist in current name space, if it exists, rename to function_internal

This looks good to me. I think it could be merged after some minor clean up. There are some bigger cleaning and refactoring needed for future development but that is not a big problem because the code are self-contained in the example directory. We can push that after GTC.

BTW: @yzhang87 can you copy and paste some representative pieces of running logs to the readme so that people know what to expect when then run the program successfully? Also it might help to add a reference run time and performance -- roughly how long does it take and around what accuracy after finishing it. I think this is very helpful for user to verify whether they run it successfully.
I think it might worth checking other use of `FlatTo2D` to make sure all are anticipating the expected behavior.
I used the old executor API. tested a bit on Mu's CI mahine, adding GPU can indeed get some speedup for large workload

for device placement
can you please give a rough speedup? we may include them on the slides
If you are using Rtools 3.3, please downgrade to 3.2 and try again.

There are two ways that pop out from my head:
- Use the imperative API to chain the modules, with each module binded as executor(need to manually do forward/backward)
- Rebind a executor each time on the same parameter with different graphs, using the shared executor option. This depend on how long it takes to create a new executor on the fly. We have not yet tested this, but this could still be faster than forward/backward. So if you issue asynchronize command, and generate next executor in concurrent with execution, it could be OK.

Both might require use of customized training loop or hack a bit into the model training API

The runtime regeneration is similar to bucketing, except that in bucketing the executor is cached, so also cc @pluskid for this
I see. Most operator as far as I know uses FlatTo2D for elementwise ops, so they should be fine
@pluskid can you submit a PR to fix this one first?
Thanks! I will modify it based your comments.

Is this example not using the bucketing API intentionally? I and @harouwu talked to @mli, and we are doing some benchmarking on the PTB example this week to checkout the bucketing performance on multi-GPU nodes and if any improvement can be made
I just pick the simper version for demonstration. I think the same philosophy applies to bucketing case.
I have updated it now.
Thanks! This is merged
@tqchen I have tried some smaller learning rates and  initialized weights but still find the same problem.

@thirdwing I think that I have fixed the bug. Since the `init.c` and `init.h` should be treated as input data, their gradients need to be zeros. Thus, I set their gradients to be zero in [lines](https://github.com/ziyeqinghan/mxnet/blob/11ab148a951935c091e7d0e42956a59fefd22391/R-package/demo/rnn/lstm.R#L253-L258).
@thirdwing I have changed my timing code and moved the demo into the same folder with python one. I have also rebased the master branch and combined the commits.

I agree, the easiest way that uses current high-level API is through bucketing. One potential issue is that you might end up with a **lot** of buckets depending on how you choose to drop some of the layers. But maybe you might choose to throw up old buckets or not do caching at all.
